meta.content: Co3O4 and K/Co3O4 were tested in catalytic N2O decomposition. K/Co3O4 exhibited higher activity than Co3O4, which was drastically and irrecoverably decreased with added NO. Studies revealed that the Co2+ valence state changed after NO adsorption, and that potassium strengthened the Co–NO bond, impeding NO desorption, even above 400 °C.

meta.content: Understanding the Effect of NO Adsorption on Potassium-Promoted Co3O4 for N2O Decomposition - Catalysis Letters

Abstract Co3O4 and K/Co3O4 were tested in catalytic N2O decomposition. K/Co3O4 exhibited higher activity than Co3O4, which was drastically and irrecoverably decreased with added NO. Studies revealed that the Co2+ valence state changed after NO adsorption, and that potassium strengthened the Co–NO bond, impeding NO desorption, even above 400 °C. Graphical Abstract

head.title: Understanding the Effect of NO Adsorption on Potassium-Promoted Co3O4 for N2O Decomposition | SpringerLink

div.p: Advertisement

div.div:
Understanding the Effect of NO Adsorption on Potassium-Promoted Co
3
O
4
for N
2
O Decomposition

header.h1:
Understanding the Effect of NO Adsorption on Potassium-Promoted Co
3
O
4
for N
2
O Decomposition
header.p:
Catalysis Letters
volume
147
,
pages
2886–2892 (
2017
)
Cite this article

li.p:
394
Accesses

5
Citations

div.p:
Co
3
O
4
and K/Co
3
O
4
were tested in catalytic N
2
O decomposition. K/Co
3
O
4
exhibited higher activity than Co
3
O
4
, which was drastically and irrecoverably decreased with added NO. Studies revealed that the Co
2+
valence state changed after NO adsorption, and that potassium strengthened the Co–NO bond, impeding NO desorption, even above 400 °C.

The abatement of nitrous oxide (N
2
O) from industrial facilities is a major environmental issue nowadays due to its harmful effect on the ozone layer [
1
]. The global warming potential of N
2
O is 310 times higher than that of carbon dioxide, and its annual emission into the atmosphere has been constantly increasing (0.2% per year) [
1
,
2
]. The direct decomposition of N
2
O from flue gases is a very simple and cost-effective technology, and various types of catalysts, including noble metals, pure and mixed oxides, and ion-exchanged zeolites, have been reported [
3
,
4
,
5
,
6
]. In recent years, transition-metal oxides have attracted much attention due to their high catalytic activities for N
2
O decomposition. Among them, cobalt oxide-based catalysts have shown the highest activity at low temperature (below 400 °C) for removing N
2
O by direct decomposition [
6
,
7
,
8
]. Obalová et al. investigated the application of alkali promoted Co
4
MnAlO
x
mixed oxide for N
2
O conversion and obtained excellent results in the presence of oxygen and water vapor [
9
]. They reported that the addition of alkali metals is closely related to ionization potential, electron transfer, and a decrease in binding energy [
9
]. Stelmachowski et al. studied electronic promotion of Co
3
O
4
by surface alkali dopants using the work function measurements by applying the Kelvin method [
10
]. They insisted that the surface ionization of alkali metals on Co
3
O
4
facilitates the donation of electron density to the catalyst [
10
].

Although the cobalt oxide-based catalysts show promising activity toward N
2
O decomposition, their efficiencies can significantly deteriorate in the presence of inhibitory gases such as oxygen, water vapor, and nitric oxide (NO). Considering this inhibitor-driven reduction in activity, it is important to understand the reason underlying catalyst deterioration [
11
,
12
]. Centi et al. discussed the performance of noble metal (rhodium) catalysts for N
2
O abatement [
5
]. The activity of rhodium on zirconia was very high, leading to complete N
2
O conversion at ~200 °C (gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) = 30,000 h
−1
). Furthermore, the conversion of N
2
O in the presence of oxygen and water was fully recovered to its original activity when these inhibitory gases were removed from the feed [
5
]. Franken et al. investigated the optimal Cu content for a K-Cu
x
Co
3−
x
O
4
catalyst [
13
]. The addition of O
2
or H
2
O to the feed gases slightly inhibited the catalytic N
2
O decomposition activity, but the catalytic activity was drastically decreased in the presence of NO, due to competitive adsorption between NO and N
2
O [
13
]. Shen et al. studied Co/MgO catalysts for N
2
O decomposition [
14
]. A negative effect of NO on N
2
O decomposition was observed in the presence of O
2
and H
2
O [
14
]. The inhibition of N
2
O decomposition by NO was presumably related to competitive adsorption [
14
]. Xue et al. reported that the decrease in catalytic activity was fully reversible to its original activity when O
2
and H
2
O were eliminated from the feed gas [
15
]. However, in the case of feed gases including NO, the efficiency of the catalysts could not be recovered to their original levels of conversion, although the supply of NO was interrupted [
15
]. These studies reported the harmful effects of NO on Co
3
O
4
-based catalysts, and simply assumed that NO was competitive with N
2
O for adsorption on the catalyst surface. However, a more systematic study on the role of NO in the deactivation of Co
3
O
4
should be made.

Considering the limited number of publications that describe NO adsorption over Co
3
O
4
-based catalysts in N
2
O decomposition processes, this study aims to characterize and compare the catalytic activities of Co
3
O
4
and K/Co
3
O
4
for N
2
O decomposition. The catalytic activity tests for N
2
O decomposition were conducted in a fixed-bed reactor at low temperature (below 400 °C). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), in situ Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, and temperature-programmed desorption of nitric oxide (NO-TPD) measurements revealed that adsorbed NO on Co
3
O
4
-based catalysts was not completely desorbed at low temperature due to the strength of the adsorption on the catalyst surface.

Co
3
O
4
was prepared by a co-precipitation method. The precursor Co(NO
3
)
2
(97%, Junsei) was dissolved in deionized water. The precipitating agent (K
2
CO
3
, 15% w/w) was slowly added (2 mL/min) at room temperature to the constantly stirred solution until the pH reached 9.1, and the slurry was digested for 3 h. The product was thoroughly washed with deionized water several times, dried overnight at 110 °C, and calcined at 400 °C for 2 h in air. The addition of the alkali promoter (K) was conducted using the incipient wetness impregnation method (amount of K: 1 wt%). The resulting catalyst was dried and calcined at 400 °C for 2 h.

A previous paper has reported that the K-doped Co
3
O
4
catalyst (K/Co molar ratio of 0.02) has highly improved activity when the K loading was approximately 1.3 wt% [
16
]. Based on this report, we fixed the loading of potassium to 1 wt%. To ensure the complete removal of the precipitating agent after washing or potassium doping, the potassium compositions of Co
3
O
4
and K/Co
3
O
4
were measured by ICP-MS analysis (see Table
1
).

figcaption.b:
Table 1 Composition of Co
3
O
4
and K/Co
3
O
4
catalysts determined by ICP-MS

div.p:
The catalysts were analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to identify the surface nature and concentrations of the active species. The spectra were recorded with an ESCALAB Mark II spectrometer (Vacuum Generators, UK) using Al Kα radiation (
hν
= 1486.6 eV) with a constant pass energy of 50 eV. The C 1
s
measurement at 285.0 eV was used for charging effects.

In situ FT-IR experiments were conducted in a ceramic IR cell with ZnSe windows, using a PIKE Technologies diffuse reflectance IR accessory that was attached to a Nicolet iS10 (Thermo Scientific) IR spectrometer equipped with a HgCdTe (MCT) detector. The absorbance spectra of the catalysts were collected by the KBr pellet method. Each recorded spectrum was referenced to a background KBr pellet spectrum. Before IR spectral acquisition, samples were pretreated at 400 °C in a He gas flow to remove any impurities. A gas composed of 0.5% NO/He was introduced into the cell to investigate NO adsorption on the catalysts.

NO-TPD was performed in a BELCAT-B testing apparatus (BEL Japan Inc.). Prior to the NO-TPD experiments, the samples were pretreated in a flow of 10% O
2
/He at 400 °C for 1 h, followed by subsequent purging and cooling at 50 °C under He. The samples were exposed to excess adsorptive gas (0.5% NO/He gas mixture) at 50 °C for 1 h and then purged with He. After pretreatment, NO-TPD was performed up to 700 °C in a He flow at a rate of 5 °C min
−1
.

Catalytic reactions were performed under atmospheric pressure in a fixed-bed flow reactor. Prior to each reaction, the catalyst was pretreated with 10% O
2
/N
2
from room temperature to 400 °C for 1 h, and then returned to the starting temperature. Simulated influent gases consisting of 500 ppm N
2
O or 500 ppm N
2
O + 300 ppm NO in N
2
balance were introduced into the catalytic reactor at GHSV = 45,000 h
−1
. Following the reaction with 500 ppm N
2
O + 300 ppm NO in N
2
balance, a thermal treatment at 400 °C for 1 h under 10% O
2
/N
2
was conducted, and then the decomposition reaction was performed once again under ideal conditions (500 ppm N
2
O in N
2
balance). The effluent gases from the reactor were analyzed with an infrared gas analyzer (Madur Polska, Sensonic IR-1).

Figure
1
displays the effect of NO on the catalytic activity of Co
3
O
4
for N
2
O removal. As NO is the one of the most common impurities in the feed stream of field application, the NO effect must be investigated. The catalyst partially removes N
2
O below 400 °C (Fig.
1
a). In the presence of 300 ppm NO, the N
2
O conversion at each given temperature decreases (Fig.
1
b). Exposure to NO seems to depress catalytic activity for N
2
O removal. After the N
2
O removal reaction with NO added, the NO-exposed Co
3
O
4
catalyst was thermally treated at 400 °C for 1 h in a flow of 10% O
2
/N
2
for the purpose of regeneration. After this thermal treatment, the catalytic activity of the NO-exposed Co
3
O
4
catalyst is nearly recovered (Fig.
1
c).

N
2
O conversion over Co
3
O
4
catalyst: (
a
) 500 ppm N
2
O in N
2
, (
b
) 500 ppm N
2
O + 300 ppm NO in N
2
balance, (
c
) 500 ppm N
2
O in N
2
(After thermal treatment of part (
b
) catalyst at 400 °C for 1 h under 10% O
2
/N
2
)

The same experimental procedure was applied to the potassium-promoted Co
3
O
4
catalyst (K/Co
3
O
4
). In the absence of NO, the K/Co
3
O
4
catalyst shows significantly enhanced N
2
O conversion compared to the Co
3
O
4
catalyst over the entire temperature range (250–375 °C) (Fig.
2
a). It is apparent that the addition of K to Co
3
O
4
dramatically improves the catalytic performance toward N
2
O decomposition. However, in the presence of 300 ppm NO, the activity of the K/Co
3
O
4
catalyst is drastically reduced (Fig.
2
b). Even after thermal treatment at 400 °C for 1 h in a flow of O
2
/N
2
, the catalytic activity of K/Co
3
O
4
for N
2
O decomposition is not restored (Fig.
2
c). Accordingly, it is inferred that NO remains on the K/Co
3
O
4
surface, even after thermal treatment.

N
2
O conversion over K/Co
3
O
4
catalyst: (
a
) 500 ppm N
2
O in N
2
, (
b
) 500 ppm N
2
O + 300 ppm NO in N
2
balance, (
c
) 500 ppm N
2
O in N
2
(After thermal treatment of part (
b
) catalyst at 400 °C for 1 h under 10% O
2
/N
2
)

XPS measurements were performed on the Co
3
O
4
and K/Co
3
O
4
catalysts to investigate the influence of NO adsorption on the active sites. The XPS spectra of Co 2
p
3/2
and Co 2
p
1/2
for Co
3
O
4
with or without NO are depicted in Fig.
3
a. For the pristine Co
3
O
4
catalyst, the Co 2
p
3/2
binding energy observed at 779.8 eV, and the spin orbit splitting (∆
E
) between Co 2
p
3/2
and Co 2
p
1/2
in the XPS spectra of 15 eV, are in good agreement with reference data [
16
,
17
,
18
]. However, the binding energies of Co 2
p
3/2
and Co 2
p
1/2
for the NO-exposed Co
3
O
4
catalyst are approximately 0.9 eV lower than those of the pristine Co
3
O
4
. The peak area for Co
2+
in Co 2
p
3/2
is slightly decreased (Table
2
). This suggests that the surface properties of Co
3
O
4
are changed due to the adsorption of NO. For the K/Co
3
O
4
catalyst, the Co 2
p
3/2
peaks of the fresh and NO-adsorbed substrates exhibit binding energies of 779.3 and 779.5 eV, in agreement with reference data [
16
,
17
,
18
]. The Co
2+
peak area in the NO-exposed K/Co
3
O
4
decreases, because the potassium ion dopant causes strong NO adsorption. The change in the electronic structure of Co
3
O
4
catalysts before and after NO adsorption is described by the peak area ratio, as shown in Table
2
. When pure Co
3
O
4
is used, the Co
2+
peak area ratio in the total area (Co
2+
+ Co
3+
area) did not change; in fact, it slightly increased (from 65 to 66%) after NO adsorption. This means that N
2
O decomposition in the presence of a pure Co
3
O
4
catalyst is not affected much by NO adsorption. However, when K/Co
3
O
4
is used, the Co
2+
peak area ratio in the total area (Co
2+
+ Co
3+
area) decreased from 70 to 65%. This indicates that NO adsorption by the catalyst may adversely impact the catalytic activity for N
2
O decomposition because Co
2+
is an active site for N
2
O decomposition. Figure
3
c shows the spectra of K 2
p
before and after NO exposure. The K/Co
3
O
4
peaks appearing at 295.1 eV (K 2
p
1/2
) and 292.4 eV (K 2
p
3/2
) are in good agreement with reference data [
16
,
17
]. However, the peaks of the NO-exposed K/Co
3
O
4
catalyst are shifted to slightly higher binding energies, owing to the contribution of chemical bonding between NO and the metal oxide.

XPS spectra of:
a
Co 2
p
(Co
3
O
4
),
b
Co 2
p
(K/Co
3
O
4
), and
c
K 2
p
(K/Co
3
O
4
) pristine and NO-exposed samples

figcaption.b: Table 2 XPS results for pure and NO-adsorbed samples

div.p:
Previous studies have shown that Co
2+
is the active site in Co
3
O
4
for N
2
O decomposition [
16
,
18
,
19
], and that N
2
O conversion is inhibited due to the competitive adsorption between NO and N
2
O on the same active sites [
13
,
15
]. These results apparently showed that the quantity of Co
2+
is decreased and that of Co
3+
is increased due to NO adsorption. Asano et al. reported that a redox mechanism for N
2
O decomposition over Co
3
O
4
was closely related to unsaturated Co
2+
species, and electron donation to Co species increases the number of the active sites [
16
]. A binding energy shift due to the presence of Na on a Pd/SiO
2
catalyst was reported by Pitchon et al. [
20
], who claimed that the negative binding energy shift was caused by an initial-state chemical shift and charging effects. These results indicate that NO must be removed before N
2
O decomposition reaction using K/Co
3
O
4
because NO is one of the most common impurities in the feed stream of field application.

Only a few IR studies of NO adsorption on K-doped cobalt spinel oxide have been reported [
21
]. To identify the effects of NO adsorption on surface species, IR spectra were collected for Co
3
O
4
and K/Co
3
O
4
catalysts before and after exposure to a flow of NO. All IR spectra were obtained after pretreatment of the samples in a flow of He at 400 °C for 1 h. Figures
4
a and
5
a show the spectra of Co
3
O
4
and K/Co
3
O
4
under He, with increasing temperature from 25 to 400 °C, respectively. After these experiments, NO was introduced into the cell for adsorption on the samples, followed by the introduction of He for 30 min to remove weakly adsorbed NO on the catalyst surfaces. Figures
4
b and
5
b present the IR spectra collected for Co
3
O
4
and K/Co
3
O
4
after exposure to NO at increasing temperatures from 25 to 400 °C, followed by cooling to 25 °C.

In situ FT-IR spectra as a function of temperature for
a
Co
3
O
4
in He flow,
b
Co
3
O
4
after NO adsorption. Spectra were recorded against a background of KBr at room temperature in He

In situ FT-IR spectra as a function of temperature for
a
K/Co
3
O
4
in He flow, and
b
K/Co
3
O
4
after NO adsorption. Spectra were recorded against a background of KBr at room temperature in He

After NO adsorption at 25 °C for 1 h on Co
3
O
4
, adsorption bands at 2398, 1764, 1392 (shoulder), 1364 (main), and 836 cm
−1
are observed (Fig.
4
b), whereas noticeable IR bands at 2401, 1768, 1388 (shoulder), 1353 (main), and 833 cm
−1
are detected for K/Co
3
O
4
(Fig.
5
b). The IR bands in the 2000–1700 cm
−1
range, due to NO adsorption on Co
3
O
4
and K/Co
3
O
4
, are ascribed to Co
2+
-nitrosyl and -dinitrosyl species. Nitro, nitrite, and/or nitrate compounds are observed in the 1500–900 cm
−1
region [
22
]. It has been reported that IR bands for Co
3
O
4
with
ν
(NO)
>1900 cm
−1
indicate a linear mononitrosyl Co–(NO) structure, and bands appearing below 1900 cm
−1
are due to the thermal decomposition of dinitrosyl species [
23
]. Compared to the Co
2+
-nitrosyl and -dinitrosyl bands on Co
3
O
4
, those on K/Co
3
O
4
shift to higher wavenumbers. The bond between the metal ion (Co
2+
) and NO is formed through electron donation from the
σ
orbital of NO to the empty
s
orbital of Co
2+
, and
π
-backdonation from the filled
d
orbital of Co
2+
to the anti-bonding (
π
*) orbital of NO. As K enhances the electron density of the
d
orbital in Co
2+
, this blue shift strongly indicates that the addition of K strengthens the bond between Co
2+
and NO [
24
]. Conversely, the bands due to nitro, nitrite, and/or nitrate compounds on K/Co
3
O
4
appear at lower wavenumbers than those on Co
3
O
4
. These red shifts mean that the N–O bond strength decreases because of the strong
π
-donation of the
d
orbital in Co
2+
(K/Co
3
O
4
) to the anti-bonding (
π
*) orbital of NO, compared to that of Co
3
O
4
[
24
].

The IR bands assigned to NO species on the samples gradually decrease as the temperature is raised (Figs.
4
b,
5
b). However, these NO-derived IR bands remain after cooling the samples to room temperature. This behavior suggests that the NO species adsorbed on the active sites of Co
3
O
4
and K/Co
3
O
4
are not completely desorbed at 400 °C, and causes catalyst deactivation during N
2
O decomposition.

The NO desorption profiles were recorded and are displayed in Fig.
6
. These experiments were conducted to better understand NO adsorption/desorption in the N
2
O decomposition process. The Co
3
O
4
sample exhibits very broad, large peaks for NO desorption at low temperature (below 400 °C), meaning that most of the adsorbed NO is easily desorbed from the Co
3
O
4
surface. This is in good agreement with N
2
O decomposition results (Fig.
1
), which showed that the activity of Co
3
O
4
after thermal treatment at 400 °C under 10% O
2
/N
2
for 1 h was sufficient to nearly restore the original N
2
O conversion activity. Compared to the desorption peaks from Co
3
O
4
, those from K/Co
3
O
4
at temperatures below 400 °C are small. However, the NO desorption peaks above 400 °C grow larger, meaning that the interactions between NO and the K/Co
3
O
4
catalyst surface are stronger than those between NO and the Co
3
O
4
catalyst.
NO-TPD following NO adsorption in a flow of 0.5% NO/He at 50 °C for 1 h

The changes in the TPD peak areas above and below 400 °C are quantitatively summarized in Table
3
. These results strongly suggest that the N
2
O conversion abilities of K/Co
3
O
4
are not recovered to their original level mainly due to the strong adsorption of NO on the surface of the doped catalyst. Electron donation from alkali or alkali earth metals to transition metal ions has been described by many researchers [
21
,
25
,
26
,
27
], and the interaction between potassium and cobalt oxide has a key role during N
2
O decomposition. The intended role of K on the Co
3
O
4
is to weaken the bond strength of Co–O and facilitate the desorption of O
2
from the catalyst; however, the interaction between Co and NO is strengthened in the presence of K. Therefore, N
2
O conversion over K/Co
3
O
4
is significantly decreased in the presence of NO. The main reasons for the catalytic deactivation are the strong
σ
bonding and
π
-backdonation interactions over K-doped cobalt oxide that occur between Co
2+
and NO during N
2
O decomposition [
11
,
16
,
28
]. Thus, it is difficult to desorb NO species from the catalytic surface, and therefore, the number of active sites for interaction with N
2
O decrease.

figcaption.b: Table 3 NO-TPD peak areas below and above 400 °C

div.p:
Haneda et al. investigated the desorption of NO, N
2
, and O
2
from Co
3
O
4
and alkali-doped Co
3
O
4
[
21
,
26
]. The authors proposed that NO, N
2,
and O
2
desorption peaks were closely related to the addition of alkali metals into the Co
3
O
4
[
21
,
26
]. The N
2
desorption peak at elevated temperature was attributed to the decomposition of NO
2
−
and/or NO
3
−
, which both produce N
2
and O
2
[
26
]. This indicates that NO
2
−
and/or NO
3
−
can be intermediates during NO decomposition [
21
].

The addition of K to Co
3
O
4
led to a significant improvement in N
2
O conversion under ideal conditions (500 ppm N
2
O in N
2
balance, GHSV = 45,000 h
−1
). However, this catalytic activity for N
2
O decomposition decreased when NO was introduced into the feed gases. In addition, N
2
O conversion was not recovered to the original level after thermal treatment in the case of K/Co
3
O
4
. XPS measurements confirmed that the Co
2+
content was decreased, since the adsorbed NO hindered the reduction of Co
3+
to Co
2+
. The in situ FT-IR spectra showed that NO species are formed and strongly interact with the catalytic surface, remaining thereupon after thermal treatment. NO-TPD analysis also revealed that the addition of K
+
strengthened the adsorption of NO on the Co
3
O
4
surface, and thus, the retained NO inhibited the further catalytic decomposition of N
2
O.

This study affords an understanding of the main deactivation mechanism affecting K/Co
3
O
4
in the presence of NO. This knowledge will be useful for the design of catalysts with NO immunity.
